This is because it reduces the risk of urinary tract infection which is common among critically ill patients with urinary catheters. It also avoids the need for frequent catheterizations which increase the risk of infection. Daily urinary catheter irrigation with antimicrobial agent may be effective in preventing catheter-associated urinary tract infection, but it is not suitable for this patient who is intubated and critically ill. Daily oropharynx decontamination with antiseptic agent is not indicated as the patient does not have respiratory infection or colonization. Suprapubic catheter insertion is an invasive procedure that carries the risk of infection, bleeding and other complications, and is not indicated for this patient.
